frqParts.text: Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations. Swimmer’s ear is an infection of the outer ear canal that is typically caused by water remaining in the ear after swimming. A swim instructor plans to conduct a study to investigate the claim made in an advertisement for a certain medicated ear drop. For people with swimmer’s ear, there is a difference between the proportion cured by using Ear Drop J and the proportion cured by using Ear Drop K. The instructor will randomly assign <math alttext="260" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>260</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> volunteers with swimmer’s ear to use one of two ear drops, with <math alttext="130" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>130</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> assigned to use Ear Drop J each day and the remaining <math alttext="130" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>130</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> assigned to use Ear Drop K each day. The instructor will record the number of people cured after two weeks for each ear drop. (a) Describe the benefit of randomly assigning the type of ear drop to the volunteers.

(b) Describe a process that can be used to randomly assign the <math alttext="260" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>260</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> volunteers to the two ear drops.

The following segmented bar graph shows the results of the study. (c) For the <math alttext="260" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>260</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> volunteers in the study, is there support for the claim made in the advertisement? Justify your answer using values from the segmented bar graph. Do not perform an inferential procedure.

The instructor conducted a hypothesis test to investigate the claim in the advertisement. Let <math alttext="p sub J" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>J</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> be the proportion of people similar to those in the study who would be cured of swimmer’s ear with Ear Drop J, and let <math alttext="p sub K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> be the proportion of people similar to those in the study who would be cured of swimmer’s ear with Ear Drop K. The hypotheses of the test are: <math alttext="H sub 0: p sub J equals p sub K. H sub a: p sub J is not equal to p sub K." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>{</mo><mtable columnalign="left" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>J</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></msub></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>a</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>J</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>≠</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></msub></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> (d) Explain why it is reasonable to conclude that the sampling distribution of <math alttext="p hat sub J minus p hat sub K" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mtext>J</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover></mrow><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is approximately normal.

(e) Based on the hypothesis test and resulting <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-value of <math alttext="0.086" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.086</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, what can the instructor conclude about the claim made in the advertisement? Explain your answer.
